hints.Chemical Weathering: This is the process by which rocks and minerals are broken down by chemical reactions.
hints.Biogeochemical Cycles: These are pathways through which elements cycle between the living (bio) and non-living (geo) parts of the Earth system.
hints.Soil Chemistry: This focuses on the chemical compositions, reactions, and processes occurring in soils.
hints.Isotope Geochemistry: This is the study of the relative and absolute concentrations of the elements and their isotopes using chemistry and geology.
hints.Geochemical Dating: This is a set of techniques used to determine the age of rocks, fossils, and sediments using signatures inherent in the rocks themselves.
hints.Mineralogy: This involves the study of minerals, including their distribution, identification, and properties.
hints.Aqueous Geochemistry: This is the study of the role of various elements in watersheds, including copper, sulfur, mercury, and how these elements change over time.
hints.Geochemical Classification of Elements: This involves classifying elements based on their preferred host phases in nature.
hints.Petrology: This is the branch of geology that studies the origin, composition, distribution, and alteration of rocks.
hints.Ocean Chemistry: This involves studying the chemical composition and processes of the ocean and its interaction with the atmosphere, biosphere, and lithosphere.
hints.Geochemical Anomalies: This term refers to areas where the concentration of a particular metal or element is significantly higher than the average concentration in the Earth's crust.
hints.Radiogenic Isotope Geology: This field of study involves the use of naturally occurring radioactive isotopes in order to date geological materials.
hints.Stable Isotope Ratios: This involves the study of the ratios of stable isotopes of elements, which can provide information about the temperature at the time the material formed, among other things.
hints.Elemental Abundance: This is the measure of the amount of certain elements relative to all other elements in a given sample.
hints.Geothermometry and Geobarometry: These are methods used to estimate the temperature and pressure at which a rock or mineral formed.
